lexUnit.name: t-shirt.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: a short-sleeved casual top, having the shape of a T when spread out flat.

sentence.text: He borrowed a new T-shirt from Jazz and tried to look a bit cleaner after his night in the graveyard potting shed , determined to keep out of trouble till after the competition .
He wore dark jeans and a very expensive-looking soft T-shirt in pale blue , but he looked no more forgiving a person .
He wore a white T-shirt with nothing over it or under it although it was the depth of winter .
She wore a t-shirt with the name of an American university printed on it , and denim shorts cut ragged round her plump thighs .
Many personnel were sporting T-shirts with the new THORP logo .
Tammuz pulled his T-shirt over his head .
He wore old jeans , espadrilles and a torn blue T-shirt through which spilled a lot of black chest-hair .
You could tell he was a maverick because he 's called Gavin , is articulate and wears black T-shirts for work .
I agreed , and next day they sent a photographer along to West London Stadium and I was pictured wearing my ` Pure Talent " tee-shirt with ` No Additives " inscribed on the back .
They all wore symbolic black clothes over bright yellow T-shirts and all spoke in Welsh , their statements being translated into English afterwards .
She dressed quickly in a white canvas skirt and navy cotton T-shirt .
He was wearing a T-shirt and jeans and looked perfect for the UK market .
He wore a white T-shirt , jeans and black head-wrap .
She was wearing a pink striped t-shirt and black jeans .
He was wearing a clean white T-shirt , frayed denim shorts , and navy canvas deck shoes , his dark hair already drying in unruly waves .
She longed for some proper clothes too -- having to wear one of his large baggy T-shirts was doing nothing for her self-image .
Her working gear comprised an oversized boat-necked T-shirt which had a habit of slipping off one shoulder , frayed denim shorts and flip-flops .
